Package com.github.tommyettinger.iconizer

Class Iconizer

java.lang.Object
com.github.tommyettinger.iconizer.Iconizer
All Implemented Interfaces:
com.badlogic.gdx.utils.Disposable
public final class Iconizer extends Object implements com.badlogic.gdx.utils.Disposable
Loads an OpenMoji atlas when created, then allows icons to be generated with generate(int, int, long). The icons are randomized Pixmaps showing two OpenMoji icons (one on the left half, one on the right). The colors are all randomized. This renders to a framebuffer, so it uses OpenGL and as such cannot be used on the headless backend. You can only create an Iconizer after ApplicationListener.create() has been called by the framework.

  • Constructor Details

    • Iconizer

      public Iconizer()
      Creates an Iconizer and loads its TextureAtlas from the classpath. This must be called during or after ApplicationListener.create() has been called by the framework. This cannot be run on a headless backend because it renders to a FrameBuffer using a shader, but it can be run on any other backend.
      This uses a shader to colorize the selected icons using HSL. Credit for most of the shader goes to Sam Hocevar.

  • Method Details

    • generate

      public com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap generate(int width, int height, Object... seeds)
      Hashes the given seeds and calls generate(int, int, long) with the hashed seed.
      Parameters:
      width - the width in pixels of the Pixmap to produce
      height - the height in pixels of the Pixmap to produce
      seeds - will be hashed as a group using scrambleAll(Object...)
      Returns:
      a new Pixmap generated using the given size and seed

    • generate

      public com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Pixmap generate(int width, int height, long seed)
      Creates a new Pixmap with the given width and height, using the given long seed to randomly select colors and halves of icons to draw.
      Parameters:
      width - the width in pixels of the Pixmap to produce
      height - the height in pixels of the Pixmap to produce
      seed - a typically-unique long seed for random generation
      Returns:
      a new Pixmap generated using the given size and seed

    • hsl2rgb

      public static float hsl2rgb(float h, float s, float l, float a)
      Converts the four HSLA components, each in the 0.0 to 1.0 range, to a packed float in RGBA format.
      Parameters:
      h - hue, from 0.0 to 1.0
      s - saturation, from 0.0 to 1.0
      l - lightness, from 0.0 to 1.0
      a - alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0
      Returns:
      an RGBA-format packed float

    • scramble

      public static long scramble(Object o)
      Hashes o and scrambles the hash with scramble(long).
      Parameters:
      o - any Object; will be hashed with Objects.hashCode(Object).
      Returns:
      the scrambled hash of o

    • scramble

      public static long scramble(Object o1, Object o2)
      Scrambled and hashes o1 and o2 with scramble(long). More thorough than just calling (for example) Objects.hash(Object...) and scrambling that, since Objects.hash() can only return about 4 billion results, and this can return, in theory, over a billion times as many possible results.
      Parameters:
      o1 - any Object to hash with Objects.hashCode(Object).
      o2 - any Object to hash with Objects.hashCode(Object).
      Returns:
      the scrambled hash

    • scrambleAll

      public static long scrambleAll(Object... os)
      Scrambled and hashes every Object in os, using the previous hashes to modify the input to the next hash, and so on. Very likely to be able to return all 18 quintillion possible long hashes if given at least 3-4 objects.
      Parameters:
      os - an array or varargs of Object items of any type, including null
      Returns:
      the scrambled hash, or 0 if os is a null array

    • scramble

      public static long scramble(long x)
      Given a long x, this randomly scrambles x, so it is (almost always) a very different long. This can take any long and can return any long.
      It is currently unknown if this has any fixed-points (inputs that produce an identical output), but a step is taken at the start of the function to eliminate one major known fixed-point at 0.
      This uses the MX3 unary hash by Jon Maiga, but XORs the input with 0xBBE0563303A4615FL before using MX3.
      Parameters:
      x - any long, to be scrambled
      Returns:
      a scrambled long derived from x

    • confineLowerHalf

      public static int confineLowerHalf(long x, int bound)
      Given a long x and an int bound, this randomly scrambles the low bits of x, so it produces an int between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive). The bound is permitted to be negative; it is still exclusive then. This uses the low bits only so that you can get a second bounded int with confineUpperHalf(long, int).
      This does not randomize x; use scramble(java.lang.Object) methods to do that first.
      Parameters:
      x - any long; should be scrambled with scramble(java.lang.Object)
      bound - the exclusive outer bound
      Returns:
      a scrambled int between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive) derived from x

    • confineUpperHalf

      public static int confineUpperHalf(long x, int bound)
      Given a long x and an int bound, this randomly scrambles the low bits of x, so it produces an int between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive). The bound is permitted to be negative; it is still exclusive then. This uses the high bits only so that you can get a second bounded int with confineLowerHalf(long, int).
      This does not randomize x; use scramble(java.lang.Object) methods to do that first.
      Parameters:
      x - any long; should be scrambled with scramble(java.lang.Object)
      bound - the exclusive outer bound
      Returns:
      a scrambled int between 0 (inclusive) and bound (exclusive) derived from x
